title: Divide and Conquer
content:
# Divide and Conquer
![](image-kk4psehz.png)
An inversion is when lines cross. So if you order something differently from me, the lines connecting the two same letters will cross.

![](image-kk4pxssc.png)

ok, not that great.

![](image-kk4sowxc.png)

We can use a mergesort-kind of technique.

In fact, we're really just modifying merge-sort. Don't just count the inversions, also sort. That makes it easier to count inversions.

![](image-kk4st3t8.png)

---

![](image-kk4sugw5.png)

![](image-kk5sokuv.png)

Extract all points within the strip, in sorted y order.

![](image-kk5sry2r.png)

#### Summary
![](image-kk5sxqwf.png)

There can be at most 8 in the blue region, because if there were more, then there would be a smaller solution than $\delta$, on one side.

![](image-kk5t2fp8.png)

both the sorts, and combinations, are $O(n\log n)$.

---

The length $n$ of an integer $a$ is $\Theta(\log{|a|})$
It's stored as an array of `unsigned long`.

![](image-kkig9csb.png)

So let's look at the recurrence here.
